 002: Basic Python Lebwohl-Lasher code.  Based on the paper 
 003: P.A. Lebwohl and G. Lasher, Phys. Rev. A, 6, 426-429 (1972).
 004: This version in 2D.
 005: 
 006: Run at the command line by typing:
 007: 
 008: python LebwohlLasher.py <ITERATIONS> <SIZE> <TEMPERATURE> <PLOTFLAG>
 009: 
 010: where:
 011:   ITERATIONS = number of Monte Carlo steps, where 1MCS is when each cell
 012:       has attempted a change once on average (i.e. SIZE*SIZE attempts)
 013:   SIZE = side length of square lattice
 014:   TEMPERATURE = reduced temperature in range 0.0 - 2.0.
 015:   PLOTFLAG = 0 for no plot, 1 for energy plot and 2 for angle plot.
 016:   
 017: The initial configuration is set at random. The boundaries
 018: are periodic throughout the simulation.  During the
 019: time-stepping, an array containing two domains is used; these
 020: domains alternate between old data and new data.
 021: 
 022: SH 16-Oct-23
 023: """

 239: def MC_step(double[:,:] arr,float Ts, int nmax, int[:,:] grid):
 240:     """
 241:     Arguments:
 242: 	  arr (float(nmax,nmax)) = array that contains lattice data;
 243: 	  Ts (float) = reduced temperature (range 0 to 2);
 244:       nmax (int) = side length of square lattice.
 245:     Description:
 246:       Function to perform one MC step, which consists of an average
 247:       of 1 attempted change per lattice site.  Working with reduced
 248:       temperature Ts = kT/epsilon.  Function returns the acceptance
 249:       ratio for information.  This is the fraction of attempted changes
 250:       that are successful.  Generally aim to keep this around 0.5 for
 251:       efficient simulation.
 252: 	Returns:
 253: 	  accept/(nmax**2) (float) = acceptance ratio for current MCS.
 254:     """
 255:     #
 256:     # Pre-compute some random numbers.  This is faster than
 257:     # using lots of individual calls.  "scale" sets the width
 258:     # of the distribution for the angle changes - increases
 259:     # with temperature.
 260:
